captions.text:
There's a famous scene in the Lord of the
Rings where the elf Legolas claims to be able

to count the exact number of horsemen 5 leagues
away, and on top of that can tell that their

leader is very tall. But even with the most
perfect eyes possible, would anyone be able
to see that far?

When we see, we're looking at light that's
traveled outwards from a light source, bounced

off an object, passed through the lens in
the eye, and been focused into an image on

the retina. Except... light isn't a particle
traveling in perfectly straight lines - it

is a wave. And therein lies the problem, both
for us, and for Legolas.

Because any wave - whether water, sound or
light - that travels through a small opening

will become spread out by a process known
as diffraction, which for light, essentially
blurs the image.

You can see this with a telephoto camera lens
where the camera aperture has been made very

very small - small details in the photograph
start to become spread out, blurred, and even

indistinguishable! Or, if you hold the edge
of a piece of paper in front of your eye and

try to read past it, small words will become
blurry!

The blur that a small point of light spreads
out to become is called an Airy disk, and

the size of the Airy disk for distant tiny
objects depends only on the wavelength of

light in question and the size of the opening
you're looking through. So for visible sunlight

and a human-sized pupil, diffraction limits
us to at best be able to distinguish objects

that are bigger than seven one-thousandths
of a degree, for example, an object one centimeter

in size a hundred meters away,. Another way
of putting this is that everything 100m away

and smaller than 1cm gets blurred so that
it appears to be about 1cm in size, no matter

how small it really is - subtle details smaller
than 1cm blur away.

So when Legolas, who has very human-sized
pupils, looked at the riders of Rohan 24 km

away, diffraction tells us that everything
smaller than 3 METERS would have been blurred

to about three meters in size - perhaps he
could still count the number of horsemen,

but he definitely couldn't distinguish their
heights to within a few centimeters...

Unless Legolas could see in ultraviolet. Shorter
wavelength light diffracts less, so if he

could see in the extreme UV, then he'd be
able to distinguish objects 10 cm in size,
almost enough to discern the height of a man.

Except that pretty much any kind of air absorbs
extreme UV light - so even if he could see

UV, Legolas would have been left in the dark.
Or maybe it's just... magic.

comments.text:
Their pupils and retinas. Their eyes are bigger and larger for their size 
and the retinas has a large number of receptors per square millimeter, 
which determines the degree of visual acuity. The more receptors an animal 
has, the higher its ability to distinguish individual objects at a distance.

If an elf is said to have great vision, that means they must have eyes as 
big as anime characters.

But they are magical being so physics don't apply at them.

comments.author: Jorge Javier Morzán Scerpella

comments.text:
+Michael Groesbeck So you're implying light waves are oscillations of 
photon particles (given your drop of water analogy)? You know they are not, 
right? Wave theory implies light as a wave of electromagnetic fields. And 
it really doesn't matter what your opinion on this is, there is no debate 
"Wave theory vs Particle theory". It is widely accepted and tested in 
Physics that light (and, in fact, all matter) behave in a dualistic way. In 
fact, using the terms "wave" and "particles" is a severe linguistic 
limitation in discussing quantum objects, it's not like they can be one 
thing or the other. They are something else, which the words "wave" and 
"particle" can satisfy the purpose of understanding phenomena from time to 
time. Those terms were originally used for macroscopic entities, such as a 
particle of dust and a wave of water, but they become a lot less intuitive 
when describing things in the quantum scale.﻿

comments.text:
Humans, due to imperfections in the structures of their eyes, see /far/ 
more poorly than the hard physical limit dictates -- that is, this video 
has nothing to do with humans. You missed the point; we're discussing how 
much information certain wavelengths of light can convey at a given 
distance, not how well an actual compound eye can pick it up -- the quality 
of the lens is not being considered here, only the size of the aperture and 
the distance the light travels.

I don't know how to make this more clear than the video already did. -___-

comments.author: Phoenix

comments.text:
Telescopes are able to surpass the limitations of normal eyes *because they 
have larger apertures*. If you made a telescope with a primary lens the 
size of a human pupil, it would be magnifying a fuzzy image, due to 
diffraction. Unless you're suggesting his eyes are like the Hubble 
telescope in that they're *eight feet wide*?
comments.author: ArticulateDuck

comments.text:
+ArticulateDuck Look, his eyes are like telescopes, case closed. And if 
there are anymore problems, his eyes  are like the Hubble telescope.
comments.author: BringerOfTheTruth

comments.text:
Even binoculars can't surpass the physical diffractive limitations of light 
-- they simply have larger apertures, which if you pay attention to the 
video, you'll see is one of the variables at play. But because human eyes 
are so lousy, we don't even get the benefit of the larger apertures in 
preventing loss of information by diffraction -- we mostly just get the 
near-perfect magnification that binoculars provide.

comments.author: Michael Groesbeck

comments.text:
+ZhaJiangLiu 


1. You're asking WHY something in the universe occurs? As in...First-Cause?
LOL!

The Universe has no first-cause. It has always existed. Life on the 
otherhand, has not.

2. Except a single photon affects other particles....causing exactly the 
pattern we see on the pannel.

3. Because naturally everything does. Only people are capable of going 
against the tide.....as evidenced by you & I, not budging.

4. The path of least resistance is created by the difference between the 
integrity of one group of particles bound together over the other. However, 
these bonds can be broken.

Nothing/Vacuum is neither a wave nor a particle.

Nice try though.

5. Well I technically didn't insult you, I simply recognized the external 
influence & indicated that I held a disposition toward the East.

That I don't accept wave theory doesn't absolutely mean I insulted you for 
having it. Infact, I was connecting the dots to a much broader contrast 
that dealt with entire civilizations & the dynamic between them.

I hope you appreciate me for mentioning the foundation of the philosophical 
divide that spans all subjects.

6. Quarks don't exist, therefore a pillar of Quantum Physics is knocked 
away. We are only able to observe the light that directly enters into our 
eyes...that is why quarks appear to be completely random...but give me 
enough time, tools, & tinkering & I can show that they are not.

Finished?

There is no hope for me I'm afraid. I am a damned fool & naive to take any 
such position that insists so absolutely that I should continue to have 
faith in myself & my own observation. I am so beneath every scholar that I 
must have someone demonstrate to me the folly of my 
thought.....particularly Tim, my old seifu, who emphasized that I practice 
primarily circular martial arts, when I treated it as secondary for when 
linear martial arts was not enough at the moment.

ps: Buddha, Zoroaster, & The Dragon can suck my straight, long, white, dick.
comments.author: Michael Groesbeck

comments.text:
+Michael Groesbeck 1. Exactly, that is why I am asking you why it occurs, 
which you somehow seem determined not to answer. Amazing how I have to 
repeat myself twice. How does the detector stop the formation of an 
interference pattern in a double slit experiment?

2. Still no response to my example of the diffraction of a single photon I 
see.

3. Yes, and why are these "particles" taking the path of least "resistance"?

4. Elaborate why diffraction occurs if "particles are taking the path of 
least resistance". So particles diffracting through a gap do so because 
they are taking paths of least resistance? So why are some paths more 
"resistant" than others? Diffraction of light is a phenomenon that occurs 
independent of the medium in which the light travels. If light diffracts in 
a vacuum then where does this "resistance" come from? Why do the photons 
take the paths of "least resistance"?

5. I really don't see how you could introduce ad hominem to this in any 
meaningful manner, but it is laughable that you somehow consider quantum 
electrodynamics to be simpler than having just particles. Alternatively, if 
you haven't even considered QED then, in that case, that is somewhat 
pathetic.
comments.author: ZhaJiangLiu

comments.text:

1. I didn't say it stopped anything.
2. Refraction occurs because particles are taking the path of least 
resistance through the material & Diffraction occurs because of the same 
thing.

Waves are just easier for you to comprehend than Particles.

& you're from The East or at least invest a great interest in The 
East.....figures.

This just goes to the Linear/Circular divide again.

comments.author: ZhaJiangLiu

comments.text:
+ZhaJiangLiu Did you give thought to the fact that The wall for the slits & 
the air between the wall & interference pattern itself , though it implies 
a wave, are all still composed of particles holding to & impacting the 
other, attempting to direct/deflect the energy transferred from the impact 
of the photon? Is it not possible that the photon may cause substance to 
divide & unify as it passes through?

Again, the wave is implied by us.

But I will accept if you say that the Individual (indivisible duality) soul 
is a wave....& that we do infact have the ability to be particles (inert) 
or waves (active) if we choose.

But I will never accept that The Universe by itself has as much duality as 
living beings.
comments.author: Michael Groesbeck

comments.text:
+Michael Groesbeck Please explain how light is a particle if:

When monochromatic light (multiple photons) from a coherent source is 
passed through two slits in a dual slit experiment an interference pattern 
is observed when the light hits a wall behind the dual slits. When any 
detector is used to detect photons in front of one slit or the other, 
meaning that we now detect which photons go through which slits, no 
interference pattern is observed. Why does the presence of a detector cause 
such a change if light is merely a particle?

In a similar experiment only one photon is sent per time interval with no 
detector before the slits. Regardless, an interference pattern is still 
observed. Why does this occur if light is a particle but there is, at most, 
one photon in the system at a given time?
comments.author: ZhaJiangLiu

comments.text:
+ZhaJiangLiu What was the material used to form the barriers? Were they 
dealing with more than one photon?

Then it will still produce the image of a wave, but it's still not an 
actual wave & the photons will cling together, like water pooling 
together. That still doesn't change the fact each photon is still a 
particle that is forming a relationship (within a certain range) with the 
other.

& they still begin & end as particles in that experiment.

Just because something is in motion, does not mean it ceases to be what it 
is & becomes something else.

The principle of THE WAVE is that particles are blurring together to form 
an illusion unto the observer. In reality, it is we who are doing so. 

A passing car to you may appear as a wave in a blur of cars, but each 
vehicle still intact unto itself.

I believe the uncertainty principle & theory of relativity is only useful 
in relation to ourselves...not The Universe by itself.
comments.author: Michael Groesbeck

comments.text:
Explain how light can interfere with itself in a double-slit experiment 
then. Ever heard of wave-particle duality?


Also, your logic that light consists of particles because they are 
particles is circular logic. Your ass may be shiny but it isn't very 
logical.

comments.author: Tanmay CubestormingMaster

comments.text: If science can't explain it, it's magic. Best conclusion ever.﻿
comments.author: Crafta9000

comments.text:
Truly, I love the physics lesson;  And it is very educational.

J.R.R. Tolken was writing about an ELF.  Now you could suggest that an elf 
would just be another species of humanoids;  However, the clear intent 
throughout the entire series and even in his progeny's writings is that 
Elves in Lord of the Rings have uber mind bending powers.  Such as to 
reduce the affects of aging on their mortal coil to be virtually 
nonexistent.

The Scientific Method may see it more as the documentation and research 
into Remote Viewing.  Hence, what J.R.R. Tolkien may have been suggesting 
is that Legolas was using his brain instead of his eyes.  While yes an 
author has not made a process to produce the Remote Viewing skill.  There 
have been a few people with beyond probability success rates.

I may not be right;  Yet, I favor imagining a world where more people used 
their brain more than their eyes.  The phrase "Seeing is believing" leads 
to many silly mistakes.

Another definition of magik is simply a process that is unknown.  For 
instance, a stereotypical Spanish Inquisitor would think a television is 
"magik".  Science is a process to 'discover' the Prime Material.  Even when 
science manufactures a starship that can go to warp speed, there will be 
more processes that are undiscovered than known.﻿

comments.author: James Connolly

comments.text:
Applying science to fantasy is stupid, but the logic of the book is not 
perturbed by this exercise. He is not mortal. He is an immortal being that 
can see beyond what is transmitted by light. That's part of Tolkien's 
writings.﻿

comments.text:
Clearly Legolas gets around this problems by using both his eyes as an 
interferometer. So he should be able to tilt his head to the side to tell 
the height of the riders.

That or Elves have huge anime-sized eyes. That works too.﻿

comments.author: Michael Ballew

comments.text:
+Michael Nyholt
 Better material doesn't help. This is a hard limit on the information 
carried by the light that goes through a patch of a given size. It is a 
property of the light itself, not of the eye.

into account that Legolas' eye lenses could be made out of better material 
than human eye lenses.
